title: Cédric Jubillar's defense delivers remarkable closing argument
subhed: In closing arguments, Cédric Jubillar's lawyers called for their client, accused of murdering his wife, to be acquitted. The verdict is expected on Friday, October 17.

title: France's last military pigeons, custodians of a fading tradition
subhed: The Mont Valérien fortress west of Paris houses the last military dovecote in Europe. In an era of ultra-technological weaponry, the carrier pigeon now flies only for official ceremonies, but remains a powerful symbol of the army's history.

title: What does a 'suspension' of France's pension reform actually mean?
byline: By Romain Imbach, Noa Moussa and Lili Pateman
subhed: Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu has proposed a temporary halt to a contested 2023 pension reform that increased the legal retirement age to 64. Yet is the suspension even guaranteed to go ahead?

title: Taxing the super-rich? The 'Zucman tax' explained
byline: By Allison Zarouri, Félix Pommier (motion design) and Sinead McCausland
subhed: A proposal to tax the super-rich by a French economist called Gabriel Zucman has taken center stage in debates about France's budget as Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu tries to stifle another governmental crisis.

title: First Wap, a discreet cyber-surveillance firm tracking journalists, public figures and corporate executives
subhed: Little known to the public, this long-standing player in the surveillance industry has been selling phone-tracking technology for more than 20 years, including to authoritarian regimes. Among its targets: a journalist investigating the Vatican, an Airbus employee, and Hollywood actor Jared Leto.
